Speaker.P: It makes a change to hear this Coalition Government acknowledge just how serious the situation is. Even more, it makes a change to hear them propose to take some steps which, however ineffectual and belated, are designed to tackle the problem we are facing. The picture with which we are faced is frightening. The Minister for Finance has painted in a number of the details, but he did not paint them all in. It would take him far too long to do so.

MainHeading.P: At the moment our economy is in the most dire straits. Inflation is virtually out of control. Unemployment, already at unprecedented heights, is rising. The volume of retail sales is down. The volume of our industrial exports on which we have lived for so long and based our growth is practically static. Our balance of payments deficit is at a dangerously high level and held in control for only one reason—because of the downturn in our economy.

Agriculture, which went through so much under this Government, is now facing an even worse situation. The situation in the cattle industry is grim. As the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries has acknowledged, there has been a disastrous fall in the utilisation of fertilisers. All this adds up to long-term loss.

As the Minister indicated, there is not only no growth in our economy, but there is a contraction—it is getting smaller. Now, at last, the Coalition Government, with which this country is saddled, acknowledge that inflation is our major problem. Unless inflation is tackled effectively all other problems, especially unemployment, will get worse. Already inflation here has cost thousands of jobs because it has priced out of the market goods produced in factories here, whether sold at home or abroad.

If you put yourself in the shoes of a foreign investor and take a look at what is happening here because of inflation, the heights to which it has been allowed to go and the effects that has had on wage rates, would you seriously consider setting up a business here so long as that kind of thing is allowed to go on? It would be cheaper to set up your operation in the United States of America.

Inflation has also caused grave hardship to old people on fixed incomes and pensions. As I said in this House before, inflation is the greatest force there is for the redistribution of wealth in the wrong way—making the poor poorer. Of course, none of this news to anyone, except the members of that Government.

The pattern of this Government's actions up to now, apart from their words, and it is their actions that count most, has been a total disregard of the inflationary effects of the increased taxation they have imposed, of the price rises they have allowed for Government services, of the large budget deficits for unproductive purposes—and these deficits were, in the main produced because of political weakness and not for economic reasons—of the inflationary effects of excessive Government borrowing and the cost of servicing the national debt. All these things have been totally ignored by this Government. To listen to the Minister for Finance today one would think that this was a new problem which had suddenly hit him and that he, or any of his colleagues, had no responsibility for the situation in which we now find ourselves.

Incidentally, on this sombre day, I might be permitted to introduce a little note of light relief by quoting a very eminent economic expert, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, who defined in this House what an inflationary budget was. As reported at columns 127 and 128 of the Official Report of 28th April, 1970, he said:

...what is illegitimate and irresponsible is to produce a budget which, far from having even a small surplus, is likely to produce a deficit and which will inflate the economy further. In simple terms, the Government have lashed out £22 million in extra expenditure and increased taxation by a net £12½ million.
That is what an inflationary budget means. It is a budget on which decisions taken by the Minister involve increasing expenditure more than increasing income.

As I say, I introduced that merely for light relief. It is not a situation really for light relief. All of these inflationary factors for which the Government were directly responsible, and which they totally ignored, were pointed out by us at the time of the Coalition's first budget and consistently ever since. We were not just preaching. I would remind the House that we practised what we preached. In our last budget we imposed no new taxes while giving substantial income tax relief and social welfare benefits.

Our objections, consistently expressed, were dismissed from the other side of the House and in certain other quarters as being either sour grapes, ignorance of economics, or sabotaging the national interest. I would suggest that it can now be seen clearly which side of this House understood economics and who was serving the national interest. For far too long this Coalition have tried to blame oil prices and world trading conditions for what has been happening here. They pretended they could do nothing about inflation. Of course, most of our competitors who are dealing with the same increases in oil prices and the same difficulties in world trading conditions have inflationary rates between one quarter and one half of our inflationary rate. The difference is that their Government tackled inflation. Our Government made it grow, deliberately and for short term political advantage.

The attitude of the Minister for Finance can be very well documented and I propose for the record to quote some things stated by the Minister for Finance in connection with the budgets of 1973, 1974 and their first budget of 1975. They all illustrate what I might call the confidence trick attitude that has been expressed by the Minister and his colleagues consistently up to now. Speaking in this House on 16th May, 1973, as reported at column 1286 of the Official Report the Minister said:

Everybody's prospects are being substantially improved by the growth in economic activity resulting from the massive injection of a 27 per cent increase in public capital expenditure and the expansionary effects of this budget. There are new opportunities for investment in an expanding economy which is being prudently managed.
On 3rd April, 1974, in connection with the next budget, as reported at column 1460 of the Official Report the Minister said:

As I have indicated, the Government have decided to provide a further boost for the economy in the current budget, on top of that arising from the level of the public capital programme, by not increasing taxation to cover the deficit. The injection of additional purchasing power into the economy, through the opening deficit, the income tax reliefs and the social welfare benefits, is expected to raise the national output, over what it would otherwise be, by one percentage point in this calendar year and by one-and-a-half percentage points in the 12 months to March, 1975. Increased economic growth will, as it did last year, generate additional revenue and reduce the deficit.
My budget today has three main aims.
The economic aim this year—as it was last year—is to promote growth and ensure that the economy operates at a level close to full utilisation of capacity.
One has to listen to and read these extracts in the context of what is happening in the country.

Speaker.P: The man who is not listening is the man who should be listening. He does not like listening to his own words.
In January of this year, speaking on the budget which he introduced then, as reported at column 243 of the Official Report of 15th January, the Minister said:
The tax adjustments and the allocation of increased funds to stimulate employment, production and demand, qualify this budget for the description “carefully expansionary”.
Six months ago he said that.
Read that one again. That is good.

I have taken only a few examples. There are many others. They indicate the tone of what was being said by the Minister and all his colleagues. That was as late as six months ago and then we have the picture presented today, a much truer picture, let me add, than we have had before and, as we know from the steps announced today, a much more serious situation than was ever admitted by the Minister before. As I said, we on this side of the House have consistently said——
The Deputy said nothing.

The Deputy has given me a good excuse to read out more than I intended to. From the introduction of the first budget by the Coalition consistently on this side of the House we have pointed out the direction in which their policies or lack of policies were leading us, to where we find ourselves today.
Speaking in this House on 16th May, 1973, on the Minister's first budget, as reported at column 1310, I said:

A major test of this budget will, of course, be whether or not it is effective from the point of view of its effect on prices and income inflation. I could hardly believe my ears when I heard some of the proposals which are clearly, and this must be in the knowledge of the Minister for Finance, going to cause further price increases, apart altogether from the direct effect of the increased taxation he is putting on. He must know of the effects on prices of what is contained in this budget.
Just over two years ago, on 13th June, 1973, as reported at column 382 of the Official Report, I said:

I want to say here and now, and I want to go on the record as saying, that the action of the Government in this budget will increase prices substantially, directly and indirectly, and the indirect effect may well be worse than the direct effect.
On the same day, as reported at column 395, I said:

MainHeading.P: As far as we are concerned, the budget has demonstrated clearly the incompetence in economic management of the Government. The full consequences of that incompetence will not appear for at least two years but in the meantime enough had happened for people to be very concerned for themselves and for the future of our economy.
In 1973, also on 11th July, at column 702, I am reported as saying:

He will see the price of every commodity other than food, whether it is an essential item such as clothing, footwear and fuel or whether it is a less essential or even luxury item, increasing because of deliberate Government action. This is in addition to the increased prices which are coming as a result of what might be called normal inflationary pressure. In those circumstances I cannot imagine any overall approach to our economic problems which could be more ill-conceived or mistaken than that adopted by the Government and outlined in the Bill.

For the sake of the public and of our economy generally, I very much hope I am wrong in that assessment but unfortunately, there are indications already that I am right. I am as sure of this as I can be of anything, that at budget time next year it will be clear to every man, woman and child that this Bill, in the taxes it imposes and the general approach to the problems of the economy which it embodies, is a disaster.
On 3rd April, 1974, at columns 1478 and 1479, I am reported as follows:

In our economic circumstances, some of which are outlined by the Minister in his speech, and having regard to the international climate, particularly in relation to oil prices and the shortage of various raw materials, it is gross irresponsibility on the part of the Government to bring in a budget providing for a deficit of more than £66 million. Having regard to the constraints in the supply of raw materials, the effect of the increase in oil prices and the consequent limited capacity of our economy to grow in the coming year, any stimulus to the economy above its capacity to grow is a direct production of inflation by the Government. It is not by the workers, the trade unions, the shopkeepers or the industrialists, it is by the members of the Government.
On 15th January this year at column 276, I am reported as follows:

My fear is that the deficit announced today may well go the same way, with the same serious consequences. Time is running out for us. We do not have the time for the Minister for Finance to discover a long time afterwards, as he did in the other areas I have mentioned, that we were right. We just do not have that time. There is an opportunity this year, I believe, to take our economy by the scruff of the neck and get it moving again but the Minister did not do that in this budget and we will all have to suffer the consequences.
Today we are hearing of the consequences, six months later. Finally, on 15th January this year, at column 274 I said:
We know what happens. I described that budget——
that is the one of April, 1974

——as fraudulent and irresponsible. If one looks at what has happened since, I wonder was I wrong. I ask that the Minister learn from his experience of the last nine months. He should stand back and have a look at what he is doing. What has he done to stimulate the economy? How much of this deficit of £125 million will stimulate the economy? How much of it is geared and directed to that purpose? I suggest that a very small portion will be channelled in that direction.
We know now how much stimulation or lack of stimulation there was in the economy provided by the budget introduced by the Minister in January of this year.

Quite a number of the steps announced today such as the subsidies on food and the benefit to electricity and gas, reduction of VAT rates, aid to the building industry and so on, are all things which were being spelled out by us for a very long time. They were urged by us quite a long time ago but I spelled them out in considerable detail in a speech I made in Cork on 9th September, 1974. We spelled them out again as part of a comprehensive package to tackle the emergency situation which this Government had produced, before the budget in January. But the Government did nothing about it. That is the crucial matter and I shall come to it later—why the Government did nothing about it at that time.

If the House will bear with me for two more quotations I should like to get it on record that we did urge the Government to take the steps, most of which they are now taking. That is on the records of the House and I want to prove it but I am not doing so merely to take the line of “I told you so”, although it is perfectly legitimate for us to point out that we knew what we were talking about in regard to the economy while the Government, with all the resources available to them, did not. Apart from that, there are two other very important reasons why I think this position should be made clear. The first is that the cost of the steps which the Government announced today and which we urged last autumn is now approximately 15 per cent higher than it was then.

Speaker.P: Hear, hear.
The other important reason is that in the meantime and directly as a consequence of the Government's delay thousands of jobs have been lost.
Hear, hear.

That is at the door of the Government and I hope they will be able to explain it to those who lost their jobs. At that time we suggested that there was an emergency situation and, as a method of dealing with it, that there should be quite substantial borrowing. The Government went ahead with substantial borrowing but used it in the main for purposes which were neither productive nor designed to reduce inflation. The result is that today we hear the most frightening figures which the Minister airily reduces by £30 million, £40 million and in one case, £50 million pending discussions with the Central Bank or the associated banks. This is all on top of the money the Government have already borrowed and they have virtually exhausted our credit.
To put it on the record I want to quote this. On 15th January this year, at column 272, I am reported as follows:

If we consider what happened during the course of last year we find that if the Minister had taken the steps we were advocating in the autumn—to bring in either temporary food subsidies or certain other kinds of subsidies, to reduce VAT and to take other measures in respect of certain categories of people —people would have been able to buy more. They would have kept up demand because they would get more for their money, thereby sparing many workers a Coalition Christmas on the dole.

This would have meant, too, that the cost of living payment due in March under the escalator clause would have been only 6 and not 10 per cent and that firms now facing enormous liquidity problems would have had a less severe demand for extra cash with the inevitable increases in consumer prices that follow this situation. Last autumn the Minister was blinded by the economic blizzard he had created for himself. He had no idea of what course he ought to have steered the economy on. It seems to me that he has no such idea yet.
The final quotation in this regard is also from 15th January of this year, at column 273, where I am reported as follows:

MainHeading.P: There is an emergency facing business which requires immediate action. What the Minister did today is a step in the right direction, but it does not go nearly far enough. I ask the Minister to think again about that and to do something worth while for business. Otherwise, he might well find that many of the estimates on which he based his figures will turn out to be totally wrong because the businesses and the employees from whom he is hoping to collect taxes and other duties will not be in a position to pay because businesses will have closed down.

Of course, the Minister could have given specific help to certain industries. For example, for the expenditure of a few million pounds he could have restored the situation of the house-building industry with an enormous impact on our economy. But not a word on that. He could have announced the steps which should have been taken long ago to give some degree of protection to the textile and footwear industries. But we did not hear anything about that either.
It was last January that I was telling the Minister that and still nothing done.

Instead of tackling the basic economic problems of the country which have been getting more and more serious under this Government, what were they doing? First, they were wasting the time and energy of themselves, of the Civil Service and of Dáil Éireann in damaging and irrelevant measures like the wealth tax which, on the Minister for Finance's own admission, will not redistribute wealth and will yield approximately £1½ million in a year.

But the Government were doing something else. They were also wasting time and energy on a totally artificial controversy about the re-broadcasting of BBC. Could there be a clearer indication of this Coalition's silly and tawdry priorities? While the economic situation grew steadily worse the Government said they could not do anything about inflation and they publicly abdicated their responsibility while they waited and relied on the action from other Governments to benefit them. In the meantime, they said. “We will concentrate on protecting jobs”. Look at what has happened. How unsuccessful can a Government be in achieving their objectives? Of course, the true explanation, by now, should be clear to everyone. This Coalition has been the most complacent Government that this country has ever had, including the previous Coalition, and when they finally recognised what was happening they were beset by inertia and paralysis of will and what we have heard today is brought about only by desperation on the part of the Government and the imminence of economic chaos.

There are questions arising out of this which the Government must answer. If they do not answer them here they will have to answer them to the voters. The first question is: why did they not know what we knew about the economy and, if they did know, why was no action taken until now and, if they did not know, why did they not give consideration to the suggestions that we proposed and act on them then instead of waiting so long at the cost of so many thousands of jobs?

At the time of the last budget, in January, the Government knew, as everybody did, that the national pay agreement was being negotiated. Why did they not frame their budget in January in such a way as to reduce the rise in the consumer price index, as they are now trying to do, and thereby reduce the level of pay rises under the national pay agreement, as we had advocated, and thereby save jobs and get our economy moving even to a limited extent?

As I said earlier, this Government have made many mistakes, have had many failures, but perhaps the most crucial or certainly one of the most crucial has been that they introduced in January a budget knowing precisely what the situation was, knowing there was a national agreement coming up, and they failed to take the steps that they are now taking today at greater cost. Why did they not do that in January?

The success, if any, to attend the measures announced today depends to a very great extent on the gamble of a renegotiation of the national pay agreement, and whatever the outcome of such negotiations the Government are seriously endangering any further national pay agreements. The parties to the national pay agreement did what the Government asked them in their White Paper on national partnership but the Government failed miserably to do its part in the January budget.

Workers who have received the first phase under the national pay agreement have, in fact, received a smaller increase than the cost of living in the relevant period, and they are now being asked to agree to renegotiations under much more difficult circumstances. I am asking the Government, and there will be many other people asking the Government, what is known now about the likely trends in the consumer price index that was not known in January? If it was known in January, as we knew and everybody else knew—presumably the Government knew what the trend was going to be—what excuse can the Government offer for introducing in January a budget that was not doing the kind of things the Government are doing today, things which we had been telling them long before that they should have been doing? That is the question the Government will have to face. That is the question to which they must give an answer. We know what the answer is but we will be interested to hear the Coalition's reply to that question.

This whole performance of this Coalition Government is a monument to their incompetence but with the gravest implications for the future in regard to national pay agreements and many other areas of our economy. The Government are now asking everyone else to show discipline, to show restraint, in the national interest. Why have the Government not imposed on themselves the same discipline? I was working on figures before I heard the Minister's speech. This is probably out of date, but up to the time the Minister made his announcements today they had almost doubled Government expenditure, both current and capital, in two years. The charges under their direct control, such as postal charges and television licences, were inordinately increased, and various State bodies have been allowed by the Government either to by-pass the National Prices Commission or have been allowed increases far higher than were recommended by the National Prices Commission. None of this kind of freedom is open to any other sector of the economy. Yet the Government engaging in this kind of self-indulgence asked—and I would like to know by what right they ask since they do this—that other people should exercise the discipline and restraint which is singularly lacking in all the activities of this Government up to now.

Speaker.P: And the Government increased their personal staffs by 16 per cent.
Half the Labour Party are now civil servants.
And peace commissioners.

There is an aspect of our economy which the Minister did not touch on at all today and which is of vital importance to us. I have referred to it in this House on a number of occasions. The truth of the matter is that as a direct consequence of the increase in oil prices, if we were merely to maintain our consumption of oil as it was before the prices went up we could not do anything other than suffer a reduction in our standard of living unless we step up our exports earnings to compensate for that. It is clearly one of the first priorities and should have been so regarded as soon as the oil crisis broke.

I spoke about it in this House on 8th May, 1974. At that time, the Minister for Industry and Commerce apparently was totally bereft of any idea of anything that could be done to assist the export trade, so I told him that he might have a look at the scheme for credit for exporters which we introduced some years previously on an experimental basis, that it had worked and worked well, and that now was the time to expand it. That was May, 1974. Nothing happened until one year later, May, 1975, when the Minister for Industry and Commerce announced—or it might have been the Minister for Finance at Killarney—that a scheme had been renegotiated with the banks and everything was okay.

MainHeading.P: That was a disgraceful delay considering the vital importance of it, but imagine my horror when I was told only a few days ago by one of our very large exporters that when he went along to his bank to avail of the facility he was told: “That scheme has not been fixed up at all yet.” He could not get any details because they could not get any details from the Government. The Minister will probably know whom I am referring to because I have been informed that the firm have written to him and to the Minister for Industry and Commerce about this in the last few days.

This is just a vignette of the kind of negligence and inertia that this Government have been engaged in and it has led us to what we had to listen to today. We have had, of course, the most enormous borrowing by this Government and we will have a great deal more of it, but I wonder how much of it will be of any assistance in increasing production or even in fighting inflation. I know that the Government have been scraping the bottom of the barrel here and abroad. I got figures from the Minister for Finance some time ago in reply to a parliamentary question in regard to how badly they were scraping the bottom of the barrel, figures which are frightening almost. They show that the national loan sinking fund accounts, which had £47 million in them when we left office had, at 31st March this year, £100,000. The savings certificate reserve fund, which had £7.9 million when we left office, had nothing in it at 31st March this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: What a Minister for Finance.
I expected this. I find the whole conduct of our affairs frightening in the extreme.
Could the Minister tell us how those people will be paid?

I want to refer to some of the measures the Minister announced today. The subsidies on CIE fares which were announced are welcome. It is relatively one of the cheaper ways of reducing the consumer price index because the index is out of date. I want to draw the Minister's attention to one aspect of this. CIE have already reduced their provincial services and only yesterday it was reported that they were planning much more major reductions in these services. Already there are many people who have no public transport to their work because it is just not available to them, and if the activities of CIE that have been reported continue, more people will be without public transport to get to work. The reduction in the fares will be no help to them. They are the people all over the country outside urban areas. The announcement of help for the building industry, while limited, seems to suggest either that the Minister for Local Government has been misleading the House——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: He would not do that.
——or else the money will be wasted. If he is to be believed, there is an all-out programme, no shortage of money—it never has been held up for lack of money. What are we putting money into that for?
Just heaping fat on fat.
Maybe there is another explanation. I suspect the Minister for Finance would hardly be so silly as to provide the money if what the Minister for Local Government has been saying were true.
It is not. There is no danger of that.

The effects of what the Minister announced will have to be calculated—it will take a little time—but I rather suspect that what he announced in regard to both the increased interest rates on house loans, whether SDA or building societies, and the reduction in the term of repayment in SDA loans from 35 to 30 years, all add up to a significant increase in outgoings for the ordinary household.
Already overburdened.

We have heard from the Minister that the commercial banks propose to make available a sum of £40 million for house loans in a two-year period. This money is presumably available because the private sector is unable to avail itself of the credit: it is so far down on its knees that it cannot take loans because it cannot pay them back. Therefore, this money is available. But the question I should like to pose in this regard is this. If the commercial banks advance £40 million on house loans, which are long-term loans, and if the economy ever gets off its knees again, will the effect be that the private sector will be totally squeezed for credit because the banks will have lent £40 million long term, money that has been left to them when the Government had not squeezed the rest out of them to satisfy their voracious borrowing requirements? In the long term, that could be a serious matter.

The question of extending the PAYE system is one on which I noted he was very vague. He did not say when it would happen or what the effect would be on the Exchequer. Quite clearly very careful phasing will be needed in this regard, but the Minister will want to give an absolute assurance that in the process of what he is doing people will not be double taxed——
Hear, hear.

If only from the point of view of the administrative difficulties but also having regard to the kind of confidence tricks we have become used to from this Minister, there is a danger that many people affected by this could find themselves double taxed and then given the right to appeal to get their money back. When they do get it back is another matter.
The Minister should clear up the point.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I see the Minister for Foreign Affairs is enjoying his dilemma.

The Minister will no doubt in due course think up an answer to it. All of the subsidies on bread, butter, milk CIE fares, gas, are steps in the right direction, but why so late, why when they are costing 15 per cent more, why now when they have cost so many thousands of jobs? Why did they not do it when we told them to do it? Why did they not do it in January at the lates? We urged all of those things including the abolition of VAT on electricity, but it was not feasible or worthwhile. I had an amendment down to this year's Finance Bill trying to get VAT off electricity for old age pensioners.

The employment premium is an imaginative gesture and I congratulate the Minister on it. However, I am not sure as to how it will work. I suspect that it may not work as well as one might think, but to the extent that it will work, it is a good idea. I am concerned that the Minister has not a notion as to whether it will work or as to its cost. The large figures of deficits and so on that he has been giving us do not take account of that. At the same time, it is the right kind of approach.

The Minister tells us that the current budget deficit of £241.6 million is £116.3 million more than that projected in January which was only six months ago. Surely this increase requires some explanation. Much of it is due to the extra cost involved in the Government's delay in doing what we urged them to do. That figure, huge as it is, probably does not include the cost of the social welfare improvements that are due in October, or the cost of the employment premium announced. All of this adds up to the likelihood of our having a third budget this year in order to produce the money needed for the social welfare benefits and the employment premium, if nothing else.

MainHeading.P: There are aspects of the income tax surcharge which ought to be referred to. First, it seems clear that if one is in the 35 per cent tax band and, consequently, becomes liable for the surcharge, he will pay the same extra income tax regardless of whether he has no dependants or of whether he has ten dependants. The Minister may correct me if I am wrong but that is as I see it. The surcharge is on the income tax after taking account of the allowance for dependants and so on. Therefore, so far as the implementation of this surcharge is concerned, the Government do not care whether one is supporting 12 children or is supporting only oneself. That would appear to be a major flaw and drawback in this proposal, and one which I trust will be remedied by the Minister during discussion on the Finance Bill. It would be grossly unjust to have it operate in this way.

Another aspect of this which mystifies me a little is that, speaking in this House a little more than two months ago, the Minister said, as reported at column 1581 of the Official Report for April 15th:

Nominal incomes in Ireland are, in fact, in real terms worth much less than in any other European country I know of because of the very high levels of tax associated with brackets of income, the thresholds of which are below those applicable in other countries. In order to try to cool the situation for top executives' salary demands, which will have a beneficial effect I believe right down the line, we consider it is appropriate in the income front alone, if wealth tax were never to be contemplated, to make these adjustments in the thresholds and the rates.

The Minister said that at a time when he reduced the top rate from 80 to 70 per cent. Two months later he introduces a 10 per cent surcharge. Whatever the merits or demerits of the proposals today what really emerges is that here is a Minister who does not know from day to day what he is doing.

Speaker.P: Hear, hear.

There is no consistency in the approach of the Government to economic matters. In respect of the measures announced today the first question to be asked is whether they will work. The impossible position into which the Government have got themselves means that whether these proposals work depends to a great extent on bargaining between the employers and the trade unions in order to have even a limited effect on our economy. However, the Government do not control this but they are gambling on it. Even if it worked to a limited extent these measures will not tackle our basic problem. As I have been demonstrating, the Government have no overall plan. Today the Minister told us that they could not have any such plan but he seemed to be suggesting that given certain circumstances he might contemplate an overall plan. Obviously, somebody has been twisting his arm but not enough because he still has no intention of any such plan.

Let us suppose that instead of lurching along from one crisis to another the Government produce an overall economic plan—an unlikely event—is it not clear from their hamfisted amateur handling of our economy that such a plan could not work under their administration? They could not implement it. Anything they have done confirms their incompetence and inability in the economic field.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Gibbons Mr. J. Gibbons
Speaker.P: Hear, hear.
What this country needs now more than anything else— and this is something which cannot be measured in terms of money—is confidence.
Hear, hear.

With confidence there is virtually no limit to what can be achieved but without it it does not matter what the Government do or how much money they spend, the economy will continue on a downward trend. Because of their mishandling of our affairs up to now this Government cannot obtain the confidence of the people on whom depends the progress of our economy. That being so one must consider what should happen now. The Irish people have demonstrated time and again that, given leadership they can follow, they can achieve almost anything, can put up with all sorts of hardships in order to get this country moving but first, they must have confidence in those who are purporting to give the leadership.

What have we had from this Government? We have been drifting into ever-worsening chaos. There is nothing but inconsistency. A decision taken one day is reversed the next day because of pressure. For so long as this Government are in office nobody can have confidence in the future of our economy. The message is clear. Given the present shambles of our economy it is clear that its restoration is an unpalatable task for anyone, but for the sake of this country we in Fianna Fáil are willing to tackle and we ask those in the Coalition to get out before they do any more damage to our unfortunate country and let us get on with getting this country moving again.

MainHeading.Title: Financial Resolutions. - Financial Resolution No. 1: Income Tax.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: I move:

(1) That section 3 of the Finance Act, 1974 (No. 27 of 1974), as amended by section 10 of the Finance Act, 1975 (No. 6 of 1975), shall have effect, in relation to the charge to income tax for the year 1975-76 in respect of so much (if any) of the taxable income for that year as exceeds £1,550 of an individual (other than an individual acting in a fiduciary or representative capacity) who is chargeable to income tax for that year, as if each rate of tax referred to in paragraphs (b) and (c) of subsection (2) were increased by ten per cent of that rate.

(2) That each reference to the standard rate in section 127 (1) (e), the proviso to section 143 (3) (b) (inserted by the Finance Act, 1975), section 153 (1) (dd), section 233 (2) (b) and section 525 (1) (i) of the Income Tax Act, 1967 (No. 6 of 1967), shall, in respect of the standard rate of tax in relation to the year 1975-76, be construed as a reference to the standard rate increased by ten per cent of that rate.

MainHeading.P: (3) That section 497 of the Income Tax Act, 1967, shall have effect, in respect of repayments of income tax falling to be made for the year, 1975-76, as if “at the standard rate, at that rate increased by ten per cent of that rate or at one or more of the higher rates increased, in the case of each such rate, by ten per cent of that rate, as may be appropriate” were substituted for “at the standard rate of tax or at the higher rate or rates, as the case may be”.
(4) It is hereby declared that it is expedient in the public interest that this Resolution shall have statutory effect under the Provisional Collection of Taxes Act, 1927 (No. 7 of 1927).

This Resolution provides for an increased charge to income tax for 1975-76 in the case of individuals who are liable to income tax at the 35 per cent or higher rates. The 26 per cent rate which applies to the first £1,550 of taxable income—that is, as I explained in my Financial Statement, total income less personal allowances and reliefs—is not being altered but the 35 per cent and higher rates are being increased by 10 per cent. The yield to the Exchequer from this increased charge will be £14 million, of which £8 million will be the yield in 1975.

Speaker.P: It is very difficult to hear what the Minister is saying. Might I ask him to speak more slowly and distinctly, when we might all hear what he is rushing over there.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: If we had the decorum from the Opposition they are supposed under the rules of order to observe and remain quiet, I am quite certain my voice would be clearly heard.
Order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The additional charge will apply only in the case of individuals with total incomes exceeding £2,125, in the case of a single person, £2,470, in the case of a married man and £3,160 in the case of a married man with three children.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: I shall not go over the ground just covered by my colleague, Deputy Colley. We find ourselves in this House today trying to deal with a drastic situation. But the drastic situation did not arise only today. As has been pointed out, we knew—and the Government should have known—that such a situation existed many months ago. We not only urged the Government to take action but pointed out the type of action that should be taken. Having gone some of the way to taking some of the action that might be expected of an Opposition in trying to support a Government in such a situation, unfortunately the action, as we have indicated, is too late. Unfortunately also those who are less able to bear the brunt of that action are again being asked to pay. The only section of the community asked to make any sacrifice immediately—a sacrifice imposed by this House—are the people in the 35 per cent income tax waveband.

According to the Minister's Estimates, the value to the Exchequer is £8 million. The cost of the whole package is something in excess of £20 million. The budget deficit, estimated at some £116 million in January of this year, is now double, bringing it to something like £240 million which will have to be found by borrowing.

Nobody else is asked to make any contribution to today's package, or to the £240 million deficit, except those least organised and who are always called upon to make contributions when the Government look for some input into the economy. People now with an income rate of £1,500 to £4,300 per annum will be called upon, this year, to pay an increase of anything from £1 to £100. These are the people on whom the Minister relies to give new impetus to the manufacturing industry by reducing the rate of VAT, that is the rate of VAT on clothing and footwear. These are the kind of people on whom the Minister can depend to give that impetus. But he is going to take the kind of impetus that they could give, through enjoyment in the reduction of the VAT rate from them in this fashion.

MainHeading.P: Apart altogether from registering our protest about the imposition of this tax by voting against it—as we propose to do—we intend to register our protest at the ineptitude and tardiness of the Government in handling this problem; in making a bad situation, bad as it was in the winter of last year and spring of this year, worse by their tardiness, their lethargy and ineptitude in the handling of the whole economic spectrum. For those two reasons we propose to vote against this Resolution.

Speaker.P: Might I ask the Minister a question on this Resolution? The Minister referred to the fact that approximately 100,000 new persons will be brought under the PAYE system. Is it intended that that change will be applicable during the course of this income tax year?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: No, it is unlikely that the arrangements necessary to bring them under the scope of PAYE will be completed within the current tax year.

When the arrangements are made will the changeover involve these 100,000 people paying, in the one year, income tax in respect of their earnings in the previous year and PAYE in respect of their earnings in the current year? Can we have a categoric assurance from the Minister that that will not happen?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Deputy can be assured there will be no double payment. He will recall that, when PAYE was introduced in 1960, there were certain adjustments made to avoid that situation. The circumstances are not entirely comparable. The different categories are not treated precisely the same even under existing practices. Some pay within a financial year; others have an entitlement to pay in arrear beyond a tax year. These are some of the matters of detail that will have to be worked out. But the Deputy may be assured that appropriate adjustment will be made to avoid the possibility of double payments having to be made.

The question I am asking is capable of a very clearcut and categoric answer. These 100,000 people at present are on a system under which they pay income tax, this year, on the basis of last year's earnings. When the changeover occurs—in whatever income tax year it happens —can we be assured they will not, in the same year, be paying income tax on their previous year's earnings and PAYE on their current year's earnings?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Yes.
Will the 100,000 all come in together, or will they be phased in?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Together.

How does the Minister seek to justify the fact that income tax, deductible at the standard rate of 35 per cent, for example, from company dividends will continue to be deducted at 35 per cent in respect of dividends payable to companies and, in particular, holding and investment companies for wealthy people; but, where the dividend is paid to a private individual, who has a family to support, the rate of tax to be deducted will now be 38.5 per cent?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Government are satisfied it would be wrong, in existing economic circumstances, to charge the higher rate of tax or to impose this surcharge on the profits of companies, and that to do so would only have the further effect of dampening the possibilities and prospects of employment.
Therefore, individuals pay higher taxation on their dividends.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I hope the Deputy will support the approach of the Government not to impose higher taxation on those entities which provide employment?

If you are wealthy enough to have a holding company or an investment company you pay 35 per cent tax but if you are a private individual trying to support a family you pay 38½ per cent tax. Thank you.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: If you want to maintain employment you do not impose more tax on companies that provide employment. If you want to be reckless and mischievous you suggest that the Government's aim is to provide excessive profits for the wealthy.
Question put.
The Dáil divided: Tá, 71; Níl, 67.

MainHeading.Title: Financial Resolutions. - Financial Resolution No. 2: Value-Added Tax.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: I move:
(1) That, with effect on and from the 1st day of July, 1975—
(a) the Value-Added Tax Act, 1972 (No. 22 of 1972), be amended by the addition of the following paragraphs to the Second Schedule—
“(xvii) clothing, including textile handkerchiefs and footwear;
(xviii) fabrics, yarn and thread of a kind normally used in the manufacture of clothing, including elastics, tape and padding materials in the form supplied for the manufacture of clothing;
(xix) sole and upper leather of a kind supplied for the manufacture and repair of footwear, and also soles, heels and insoles of any material;
(xx) (a) coal, peat and other solid substances held out for sale solely as fuel,

(b) gas of a kind used for domestic or industrial heating or lighting, whether in gaseous or liquid form, but not including gas of a kind normally used for welding and cutting metals or gas sold as lighter fuel,
(c) electricity,
(d) hydrocarbon oil of a kind used for domestic or industrial heating not being hydrocarbon oil sold for use in internal combustion engines.”,
(b) in consequence of the amendment specified in subparagraph (a) of this paragraph, the Value-Added Tax Act, 1972, be further amended as follows:
(i) by the deletion of paragraphs (xi), (xii) and (xiii) of Part I of the Third Schedule,

(ii) by the substitution, for paragraph (xxiii) of Part I of the Third Schedule, of the following paragraph: “(xxiii) fuel other than fuel of a kind specified in paragraph (xx) of the Second Schedule;”,
(iii) by the insertion in paragraph (xxiv) of Part I of the Third Schedule, after “(including greases)”, of “other than hydrocarbon oils of a kind specified in paragraph (xx) of the Second Schedule”,
(iv) by the insertion in paragraph (xxviii) of Part I of the Third Schedule, after “specified in”, of “the Second Schedule or”,
(v) by the addition of the following paragraph to Part II of the Third Schedule:
“(viii) the hiring of goods of a kind specified in paragraph (xvii) of the Second Schedule”.

(vi) by the substitution, in section 8 (3) (a) (i), of “, (xv) and (xx) of the Second Schedule” for “and (xv) of the Second Schedule” (inserted by the Finance Act, 1973 (No. 19 of 1973)) and by the substitution of “and (xxii) of Part I of the Third Schedule” for “, (xxii) and (xxiii) of Part I of the Third Schedule”,

MainHeading.P: (vii) by the substitution, in section 8 (3) (b) (ii), of “, (xii) to (xv) or (xvii) to (xx)” for “or (xii) to (xv)” (inserted by the Finance Act, 1973),
(viii) by the substitution, in section 11 (1) (b), of “, (xii) to (xv) and (xvii) to (xx)” for “and (xii) to (xv)” (inserted by the Finance Act, 1973), and
(ix) by the substitution, in section 11 (1) (d), of “,(xii) to (xv) and (xvii) to (xx)” for “and (xii) to (xv)” (inserted by the Finance Act, 1973), and
(x) by the substitution, in section 15 (2) (a) (ii), of “, (xii) to (xv) and (xvii) to (xx)” for “and (xii) to (xv)” (inserted by the Finance Act, 1973).
(2) It is hereby declared that it is expedient in the public interest that this Resolution shall have statutory effect under the Provisional Collection of Taxes Act, 1927 (No. 7 of 1927).

The resolution removes from the value-added tax by application of the zero rate the following items : clothing (including textile handkerchiefs and footwear); certain clothing and footwear materials and fuels, including electricity but not road fuels. The relief, which will take effect as and from Tuesday next, will have the effect of entirely removing the existing tax, 6.75, from the items affected. As a consequence the prices involved should be reduced as from 1st July for supplies made and paid for on or after that date. The cost to the Exchequer of granting these reliefs is £8.2 million in the current year and £27.2 million in a full year.

I should like to add, in reply to a question raised earlier, that registered sellers may continue to obtain a credit or refund in respect of any tax suffered by them on their purchase of taxable goods.

Speaker.P: I should like to ask the Minister, in the light of the wellknown difficulties in the clothing and textile industries, whether he considers the removal of value-added tax may, in fact, increase imports of such goods?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Deputy and I obviously share a concern that any increase in the demand for goods which may be generated by this reduction in price will not leak into imports. However, in the final analysis the decision as to whether or not Irish people buy Irish goods or foreign goods lies with each purchaser, but a tremendous responsibility lies on traders. It is for traders to decide whether or not their interests, and the interests of Ireland, lie with their purchasing goods manufactured by Irish people or purchasing from outside the country. I am sure there are many members, myself included, who have experienced difficulty themselves in endeavouring to buy in retail stores in this city items to which the Deputy refers like garments, textiles and footwear. Sometimes it is difficult to obtain goods manufactured in Ireland.

The principal factor in determining whether or not Irish goods are for sale or bought lies on us and not on any arrangements which governments may make. The Deputy is aware that there are constraints on us now by reason of EEC obligations which restrict the scope which we at one time had in relation to restrictions on imports. However, we have already raised with the EEC the steps which we propose to take to restrict the importation of footwear. There are special reasons why it would be possible to do it in respect of footwear which do not apply to the other items.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
